comment._content: Very interesting composition and great B&W !

comment.author: 32428096@N05
comment._content: Nice shot, the loco attached to the crane looks like it is a 'Sulzer' type. Maybe someone con confirm this?

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/32428096@N05] Yes it looks to be one of the Sulzer locos. The 'Hatch' as it was known to the likes of O'Dea and others has sure changed quite a bit since 1967.

comment.author: 54968992@N03
comment._content: God bless your eye sight (& knowledge) lads, I had to look for the loco. lol

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: The "elephant in the room" is the Cowans Sheldon steam crane, built in Carlisle. Cannot find any details yet. The Breakdown Crane Association www.bdca.org.uk/index.html

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] Two were sold to C.I.É 6 years after this photo was taken: "... Of the original population of ten ‘Modernisation Plan’ 30-tonners, six were extant in early 2009. However the two which had been sold in 1973 to CIE (Ireland) and re-gauged were scrapped in 2009 and the Severn Valley Railway's RS1091/30 was scrapped in 2010."
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 60812213@N04
comment._content: The Cowans Sheldon steam crane is at Mallow station yard. Go to the far end of the main car park. www.flickr.com/photos/abandonedrailsireland/6937792263/in...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/abandonedrailsireland] It looks to be in good nick.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content:
The crane at Mallow is marked 1920. It has an open cab and a lattice jib. Good that it has been cared for.
The crane here looks to be more powerful and has sliding windows to the cab.
No hard hats or high-viz jackets in those days.
Reminds me of my Hornby train set of years ago.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] Do you still have that train set? Bet you do!  :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] 
The train set was cast aside many years ago.
At the moment I am mapping old railways and coal mines of Scotland.
I will be a very old man when I reach Penzance on my website.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] So you're going John O'Groats to Land's End (approximately)! What a labour of love...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment._content: Super Shot, This scene has largely been swept away with the enlargement of Hazelhatch station for Kildare route project in 2009, four platforms now occupy roughly a area up to the middle center telegraph pole. comment.author: 44589582@N08
comment._content: Thanks Blackpool! handy little app that link is!! Hazelhatch here on the other side of the bridge was totally rebuilt with four platforms. h
